member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.ISharedProjectFileRegistrationService.GetOwnerProjectForSharedProjectFile(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the shared project file user project that registered use of the shared project file with RegistrationOption.SharedProjectFileOwnerProject.
member.param: full path of a (potential) shared project file
member.returns: project file full path for the SharedProjectFileOwnerProject; or null if none is found.

remarks.para: When a clear owner for the shared project file can be established, then this project trumps all projects that register with ProjectAffinity as the project that is given the ownership of the open shared MSBuild file in the RunningDocumentTable (RDT).

There normally should only be one project that registers as the user of a shared MSBuild file with "SharedProjectFileOwnerProject" flag. After this project is loaded, it would would be the project returned from GetOwnerProjectForSharedProjectFile. When this project is unloaded or removed, then GetOwnerProjectForSharedProjectFile would return Guid.Empty indicating there is no owner for the shared MSBuild file loaded.

In the case that more than one project registers with the "SharedProjectFileOwnerProject" flag, then if only one of these project is loaded (i.e. all of the others are unloaded), then the single, LOADED project would be considered the current owner for the shared MSBuild file and would be the project returned from GetOwnerProjectForSharedProjectFile. If there are multiple loaded projects that registered with the "SharedProjectFileOwnerProject" flag, then GetOwnerProjectForSharedProjectFile would return Guid.Empty indicating there is no clear owner for the shared MSBuild file. In this case, the ownership status is ambiguous.

NOTE: In Visual Studio the project that should specify this flag is the "real", top-level shared project file listed in the Solution file that wraps an importable shared project file (aka shared assets project or shared items project).

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.ISharedProjectFileRegistrationService.EnsureUsersOfSharedProjectFileAreLoaded(System.String)

member.param: full path of a (potential) shared project file

remarks.para: IN VISUAL STUDIO: This method will force all async loading of the shared project file user projects to be completed (by ASL).

members.member:
Ensures that the active user of a given shared project file is fully loaded.

The new full path to the shared project file.

remarks.para: It is the caller's responsibility to have actually renamed the file on disk, and to update all imports of this file.

NOTE: In Visual Studio this will result in: If the shared file is enabled for SCC integration, this method will invoke: * IVsSolution.OnAfterRenameProject * IVsTrackProjectDocuments2.OnAfterRenameFile * IVsSolutionEvents.OnAfterRenameProject * RunningDocumentTable.RenameDocument * etc. Otherwise for non SCC-enabled shared files this will simply call: * IVsTrackProjectDocuments2.OnAfterRenameFile

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectSubscriptionService.JointRuleBlock
member.summary: Gets the TPL Dataflow block that broadcasts current project evaluation and build state jointly, along with the previous state and a diff describing what changed.
member.remarks: Currently, this block's messages may differ from the one-type data of the other blocks. Specifically this block only publishes data when the evaluation and build rule blocks publish data based on the same version of the project snapshot, which during multiple project changes made in fast succession can result in less frequent updates than either of the other two blocks. When updates are "skipped" by this block, file renames are not guaranteed to be preserved.

member.summary: Determines whether or not this copy packager can provide data for the given set of nodes and what type of operations can be performed on the nodes.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.ICopyPackager.GetPointerToDataAsync(System.Collections.Generic.IReadOnlyCollection{System.Int32},System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectTree},Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectTreeProvider)
member.summary: Gets a pointer to data to set on the clipboard object that represents the selected nodes for each data format supported.
member.param: The types of data to package. This will be a subset of the types returned by ClipboardDataFormats.
The currently selected nodes.
The current tree provider.
member.returns: An IntPtr pointing to AllocHGlobal'd memory representing the selected nodes for each supported data format. Implementations may leave out a supported format or specify zero for the IntPtr if no data should be set.
member.remarks: GetAllowedOperations will have been called prior to any copy or drag operation. Therefore, the implementation of this method can assume that is valid for this packager assuming that the implementation of GetAllowedOperations always returns the same result for any set of selected nodes.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectChangeHintSubmissionService.HintAsync(Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectChangeHint)
member.summary: Supplies a semantic meaning behind some project change that is about to be made.
member.param: The semantic description of the project change.
member.remarks: This method must be called while holding the project write lock responsible for making the change.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectChangeHintSubmissionService.ProcessHintsAsync
member.summary: Returns a task that completes after all pending hints have been processed, and allows access to the main thread as necessary if the caller has it.
member.returns: A task that completes when all currently pending hints have been processed.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectChangeHintSubmissionService.CancelHints(System.Collections.Immutable.IImmutableSet{Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectChangeHint})
member.summary: Suppresses hints from being forwarded to hint subscribers after the project write lock is released.
member.param: The hints to cancel; or null to cancel them all.
member.remarks: This method must be called while holding the project write lock responsible for making the change. This covers the scenario of changes that had been planned and thus hinted, that were later rolled back, thus making the original hints inappropriate. Note that the synchronous stage of hint forwarding has already occurred and thus cannot be canceled. Thus this method only cancels the asynchronous after-write-lock stage of hinting.

member.value: A non-localized constant value. If null the default component name is used in the report.
member.remarks: This value should not contain any parameterized values so that a single Watson bucket collects all instances of this failure. Generally it should be left at null so that the product's reserved event name can be used.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IEnvironmentConfigProvider
member.summary: Provides environment-driven configuration information.
member.remarks:
In many cases, the project configuration that should be used is not defined within the project, but instead is taken from the environment (env. vars for example) in which the project is running. This contract allows plugins to override the project information.
This contract can exist at the ProjectService or UnconfiguredProject level, depending on whether the environment has different settings for different project types. It is recommended, as always, to live at the highest layer possible.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IEnvironmentConfigProvider.IsEnvironmentActive
member.summary: Returns true if the provider finds the environment defining the necessary information to drive the configuration.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IEnvironmentConfigProvider.ActiveProjectConfiguration
member.summary: Returns the project configuration active in the environment.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IEventDispatcherService
member.summary: A service used by any and all CPS components that interface directly with the MSBuild object model of a project to notify interested parties of changes made.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IEventDispatcherService.FireProjectChangeEventsAsync(System.Object,System.EventArgs,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncEventHandler,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncEventHandler,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncEventHandler)
member.summary: Invokes event handlers notifying of a project change.
member.param: The sender of the event. May be null if handlers are prepared for it.
The immutable event arguments to pass to each event handler. May be null if handlers are prepared for it.

Event handlers to invoke immediately, on this thread. May be null. These handlers may make cascading changes as the result of the change causing this event to fire. Handlers should expect to be invoked on the thread that is writing to the project, which may be the UI thread or any background thread. Handlers should also be aware that they are executing in the middle of what may be a bulk write operation, and that any changes the event handlers make MAY be rolled back if the overall bulk write operation fails.
These handlers are invoked when the write lock is about to be released.

Event handlers to invoke after the write lock has been released. May be null.
Clients should expect be invoked on any thread.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IEventDispatcherService.FireProjectChangeEventsAsync``1(System.Object,``0,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncEventHandler{``0},Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncEventHandler{``0},Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncEventHandler{``0})
member.summary: Invokes event handlers notifying of a project change.
member.typeparam: The specific type of type being provided to the handlers.
member.param: The sender of the event. May be null if handlers are prepared for it.
The immutable event arguments to pass to each event handler. May be null if handlers are prepared for it.

Event handlers to invoke immediately, on this thread. May be null. These handlers may make cascading changes as the result of the change causing this event to fire. Handlers should expect to be invoked on the thread that is writing to the project, which may be the UI thread or any background thread. Handlers should also be aware that they are executing in the middle of what may be a bulk write operation, and that any changes the event handlers make MAY be rolled back if the overall bulk write operation fails.
These handlers are invoked when the write lock is about to be released.

Event handlers to invoke after the write lock has been released. May be null.
Clients should expect be invoked on any thread.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IEventDispatcherService.CancelPendingChangedEvents
member.summary: Clears any pending events in this particular write lock from the queue so they will not be fired when a write lock is released.
member.remarks: This method is useful when a bulk operation ends up failing, the changes are rolled back, and the OnChanged events that have been queued up for invocation after the write lock is released should not be fired.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectAsynchronousTasksService
member.summary: A service that assists in managing project-related background tasks.
member.remarks: Imports of this interface should generally *not* be Lazy<T> imports to avoid ObjectDisposedExceptions from MEF while trying to access lazily initialize imports of this service when the project has already unloaded, particularly when such use of this service was to determine whether the project has already unloaded and/or to avoid timing issues with project unload.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectAsynchronousTasksService.UnloadCancellationToken
member.summary: Gets a token that is cancelled when the project is unloaded.
member.remarks: Any handlers registered via may be executed while background tasks are still running.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectAsynchronousTasksService.RegisterAsyncTask(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.JoinableTask,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Prevents a project unload from beginning until a given task has completed.
member.param: The asynchronous task to wait on in the event of a project unload. This task may have as its cancellation token, or as one of its cancellation tokens joined using .
A value indicating whether to handle faults from this task so it doesn't bring down the process.
member.exception: Thrown if the project has already begun or completed unloading.
member.remarks: To reduce the impact of deadlocks and to ensure reasonable project unload times, a timeout may expire and result in project unload resuming before the task is completed.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectCapabilitiesProvider.Current
member.summary: Gets the current snapshot of capabilities and versioning information, if available.
member.value: A versioned snapshot of capabilities; or null if none have been calculated yet.
member.remarks: The value for this property may be null if the capabilities have not been determined yet. When non-null, this value will be the last computed value, but not necessary the latest value considering recent changes to the project or environment. When getting the very latest value is important, get the latest value from the on this instance using ProjectDataSource.GetLatestVersionAsync.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.ProjectLockFlags
member.summary: Flags that modify default lock behavior.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.ProjectLockFlags.None
member.summary: The default behavior applies.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.ProjectLockFlags.StickyWrite
member.summary: Causes an upgradeable reader to remain in an upgraded-write state once upgraded, even after the nested write lock has been released.
member.remarks: This is useful when you have a batch of possible write operations to apply, which may or may not actually apply in the end, but if any of them change anything, all of their changes should be seen atomically (within a single write lock). This approach is preferable to simply acquiring a write lock around the batch of potential changes because it doesn't defeat concurrent readers until it knows there is a change to actually make.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.ProjectLockFlags.SkipInitialEvaluation
member.summary: Skips a step to make sure that a project is initially evaluated when retrieved using . Setting this flag can have negative side effects to components that write to the MSBuild project, so use to improve performance of bulk operations where you know re-evaluating the project is not necessary to maintain a consistent state.
member.remarks: This flag is dormant for non-write locks. But if present on an upgradeable read lock, this flag will activate for a nested write lock.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.ProjectLockFlags.SuppressReevaluation
member.summary: Suppresses MSBuild evaluation of projects while a write lock is held even if is called. Setting this flag can have negative side effects to components that write to the MSBuild project, so use to improve performance of bulk operations where you know re-evaluating the project is not necessary to maintain a consistent state.
member.remarks: This flag is dormant for non-write locks. But if present on an upgradeable read lock, this flag will activate for a nested write lock.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectLockService.ReadLockAsync(System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Obtains a read lock, asynchronously awaiting for the lock if it is not immediately available.
member.param: A token whose cancellation indicates lost interest in obtaining the lock. A canceled token does not release a lock that has already been issued. But if the lock isn't immediately available, a canceled token will cause the code that is waiting for the lock to resume with an .
member.returns: An awaitable object whose result is the lock releaser.

member.returns: An awaitable object whose result is the lock releaser.

member.summary: Obtains a read lock, asynchronously awaiting for the lock if it is not immediately available.
member.param: Modifications to normal lock behavior.

A token whose cancellation indicates lost interest in obtaining the lock. A canceled token does not release a lock that has already been issued. But if the lock isn't immediately available, a canceled token will cause the code that is waiting for the lock to resume with an .

member.returns: An awaitable object whose result is the lock releaser.

member.summary: Obtains a write lock, asynchronously awaiting for the lock if it is not immediately available.

A token whose cancellation indicates lost interest in obtaining the lock. A canceled token does not release a lock that has already been issued. But if the lock isn't immediately available, a canceled token will cause the code that is waiting for the lock to resume with an .
member.returns: An awaitable object whose result is the lock releaser.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectLockService.HideLocks
member.summary: Prevents use or visibility of the caller's lock(s) until the returned value is disposed.
member.returns: The value to dispose to restore lock visibility.
member.remarks: This can be used by a write lock holder that is about to fork execution to avoid two threads simultaneously believing they hold the exclusive write lock. The lock should be hidden just before kicking off the work and can be restored immediately after kicking off the work.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectLockServiceInternal
member.summary: Exposes the lock that protects the MSBulid object model behind loaded projects, with additional CPS-internal methods.

member.name: E:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectLockServiceInternal.ReleasedWriteLock
member.summary: Occurs when a top-level write lock is about to be released.

remarks.para: Event handlers are invoked on threadpool threads, are invoked sequentially and complete before the write lock is released. Event handlers MUST NOT attempt to acquire any kind of project lock or the writer thread and the event handler's thread will deadlock.
One use for this event is for event dispatchers that want to track which events get fired by which write locks.

member.name: E:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectLockServiceInternal.ReleasingWriteLock
member.summary: Occurs when a top-level write lock is about to be released. Event handlers are fired within the write lock.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectLockServiceInternal.CurrentWriteLockTask
member.summary: A task that is completed when the outermost write lock held by the caller is released.
member.remarks: The task is always complete when no write lock is held by the calling thread.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectLockServiceInternal.SuppressWriteLockCheck(System.String)
member.summary: Suppresses write lock check enforcement for a ProjectRootElement with a given full path temporarily. This method should be called as the expression of a C# using clause to ensure proper disposal.
member.param: The value of to allow to be marked dirty without throwing a missing write lock exception if no write lock is present.
member.returns: An object whose disposal will end the temporary write lock suppression for this file.
member.remarks: Write lock enforcement is *very* important. Please use this method with extreme care and caution. For instance, this method should only be used by a caller who has the only reference to the named ProjectRootElement, and even then write locks should be obtained whenever possible.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectLockServiceInternal.OnBeforeWriteLockReleased(System.Func{System.Threading.Tasks.Task})
member.summary: Registers a callback to be invoked when the write lock held by the caller is about to be ultimately released (outermost write lock).
member.param: The asynchronous delegate to invoke. Access to the write lock is provided throughout the asynchronous invocation.
member.remarks: This supports some scenarios VC++ has where change event handlers need to inspect changes, or follow up with other changes to respond to earlier changes, at the conclusion of the lock. This method is safe to call from within a previously registered callback, in which case the registered callback will run when previously registered callbacks have completed execution. If the write lock is released to an upgradeable read lock, these callbacks are fired synchronously with respect to the writer who is releasing the lock. Otherwise, the callbacks are invoked asynchronously with respect to the releasing thread.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectLockServiceInternal.RegisterLockHoldingMainThreadJoinableIfApplicable(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.JoinableTask)
member.summary: Registers the caller, who is waiting for the Main thread, as a project lock holder if applicable.
member.param: The joinable being used to switch to the Main thread.

member.summary: Unregisters the caller's Main thread joinable as a pending Main thread awaiter with a project lock.
member.param: The joinable previously supplied to .

member.summary: Prepare to reload a msbuild model into the project system. This is a special function should only be called by the code to reload files from the disk. In this phase, we need change the in-memory model inside the project collection, but should not check out the file through the source control system.
member.param: Full file path to the msbuild file

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectThreadingService.VerifyOnUIThread
member.summary: Throws an exception if not called on the UI thread.
Executes the specified delegate in a safe fire-and-forget manner.
member.param: The async delegate to invoke. It is invoked asynchronously with respect to the caller.
The factory to use for creating the . May be null to use the default.
The unconfigured project which the delegate operates on, if applicable. Optional if is specified.
The configured project which the delegate operates on, if applicable.
Whether and how non-fatal Watson reports are filed when the delegate fails.
Suggests to the user how severe the fault is if the delegate throws.
Influences the environment in which the delegate is executed.
member.remarks: The delegate is executed in the same context as the caller unless either or are specified. For example if the caller is on the main thread, the delegate is invoked on the main thread. If the caller is on a threadpool thread, the delegate will also be invoked on the threadpool.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectThreadingService.SuppressProjectExecutionContext
member.summary: Prevents the inner block to use the current project system related context, including current JoinableTask, project locks, and capabilites context. This should be used when a dataflow block to publish data, so the chained dataflow code won't run inside the same context as the code publishing the data.
member.remarks: It is typically used inside a using block. UNDONE: consider to change the return type to structure, after merging CPS assemblies.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.ProjectAccess
member.summary: Signifies the kind of access required on a project when obtaining a lock.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.ProjectAccess.None
member.summary: No access is required or granted.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.ProjectAccess.Read
member.summary: Read-only access is required.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.ProjectAccess.Write
member.summary: Write access is required. Writers may also read the project.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.ProjectAccess.UpgradeableRead
member.summary: Read-only access is required, but write access may be required before the read lock is released.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.ProjectAccess.SkipInitialEvaluation
member.summary: Skips a step to make sure that a project is initially evaluated when retrieved using . Setting this flag can have negative side effects to components that write to the MSBuild project, so use to improve performance of bulk operations where you know re-evaluating the project is not necessary to maintain a consistent state.
member.remarks: This flag is dormant for non-write locks. But if present on an upgradeable read lock, this flag will activate for a nested write lock.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.ProjectAccess.SuppressReevaluation
member.summary: Suppresses MSBuild evaluation of projects while a write lock is held even if is called. Setting this flag can have negative side effects to components that write to the MSBuild project, so use to improve performance of bulk operations where you know re-evaluating the project is not necessary to maintain a consistent state.
member.remarks: This flag is dormant for non-write locks. But if present on an upgradeable read lock, this flag will activate for a nested write lock.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.ProjectAccess.StickyWrite
member.summary: Causes any write lock taken within this (upgradeable read) lock to implicitly upgrade *this* lock, such that the write lock will not be released until *this* lock is released.
member.remarks: This is useful when a client is calling several methods that *may* require a write lock, and if so, you'd like to do all the work across all the methods within just one write lock rather than across several "top level" write locks. The benefits of just one all-encompassing write lock include preventing project change event handlers from obtaining read locks and reevaluating the project and raising various events before the entire set of changes are fully applied. While this is not expected to impact accuracy of reported events, it can help eliminate wasted CPU cycles processing changes that are incomplete, and keep any other threads from reading your half-updated state. This is superior than just taking an outer write lock when the outer code doesn't know for sure whether a write lock will be needed or which project files need to be "checked out" from SCC beforehand.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.ProjectAccess.LockMask
member.summary: The bitmask of all kinds of locks.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.ProjectAccess.OptionMask
member.summary: The bitmask of non-lock type options.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.UnconfiguredProject
member.summary: The UnconfiguredProject represents the set of components that are available for a given set of project capabilities, as defined by the MSBuild project instance provided.
member.remarks: Implementing classes must be multi-thread safe.

member.name: E:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.UnconfiguredProject.ProjectUnloading
member.summary: An event raised after background tasks have completed (or timed out) but before the MEF container is disposed of.

member.name: E:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.UnconfiguredProject.ProjectRenaming
member.summary: Event that is fired on the writer thread when a project is renamed.
member.remarks: Clients should attach handlers to this event if they may need to make cascading changes as the result of the change causing this event to fire. Clients should expect to be invoked on the thread that is writing to the project, which may be the UI thread or any background thread. Clients should also be aware that they are executing in the middle of what may be a bulk write operation, and that any changes the event handlers make MAY be rolled back if the overall bulk write operation fails.

member.name: E:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.UnconfiguredProject.ProjectRenamedOnWriter
member.summary: Event that is fired on the writer thread after the project is renamed.
member.remarks: Clients should expect be invoked on an arbitrary background thread, concurrently with other handlers of this same event. Progress on the thread that initiated the project change is blocked until execution of all event handlers is completed. Changes to the project are not allowed directly in handlers of this event, but read access to the project is guaranteed.

member.name: E:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.UnconfiguredProject.ProjectRenamed
member.summary: Event that is fired on a background thread after the project is renamed.
member.remarks: Clients should expect be invoked on an arbitrary thread.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.UnconfiguredProject.FullPath
member.summary: Gets the full path of the project manifest file. Maybe null if not loaded from disk.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.UnconfiguredProject.RequiresReloadForExternalFileChange
member.summary: Returns true if there has been an external change to the project file.
member.remarks: The project tracks the time it last saved the project file. If the current time of the project file matches its last save time, then there has not been an external change to the project file. We track this explicitly so we can avoid timing windows of when the OS fires its file change events. Clients like Visual Studio should ask for this property before deciding to prompt the user to reload the file.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectItemProvider
member.summary: An accessor for reading, writing and removing project items.

member.name: E:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectItemProvider.ItemIdentityChanging
member.summary: Event that is fired on the writer thread when an item's item type or item name (unevaluated include) changes.

remarks.para: This event is not fired when the evaluated include changes without a change in the unevaluated include. It is also not fired when the metadata under an item changes.

Clients should attach handlers to this event if they may need to make cascading changes as the result of the change causing this event to fire. Clients should expect to be invoked on the thread that is writing to the project, which may be the UI thread or any background thread. Clients should also be aware that they are executing in the middle of what may be a bulk write operation, and that any changes the event handlers make MAY be rolled back if the overall bulk write operation fails.

member.name: E:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectItemProvider.ItemIdentityChangedOnWriter
member.summary: Event that is fired on the writer thread after an item's item type or item name (unevaluated include) changes.
member.remarks: Clients should expect be invoked on an arbitrary background thread, concurrently with other handlers of this same event. Progress on the thread that initiated the project change is blocked until execution of all event handlers is completed. Changes to the project are not allowed directly in handlers of this event, but read access to the project is guaranteed.

member.name: E:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectItemProvider.ItemIdentityChanged
member.summary: Event that is fired on a background thread after an item's item type or item name (unevaluated include) changes.

remarks.para: This event is not fired when the evaluated include changes without a change in the unevaluated include. It is also not fired when the metadata under an item changes.
Clients should expect be invoked on any thread.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectItemProvider.GetItemTypesAsync
member.summary: Gets the set of item types this Provider works with.
member.remarks: This collection MAY be read only.

member.summary: Returns item types that exist in the current project. This is a subset of .
member.returns: Item types that have at least one item in current project

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.IProjectItemProvider.AddAsync(System.String,System.String,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Collections.Generic.KeyValuePair{System.String,System.String}})
member.summary: Adds a new item to the MSBuild project.
